result.rationale: Cyprinodon inmemoriam is assessed as Extinct because of total destruction (desiccation) of its sole habitat, a spring, by excessive groundwater extraction. Sampling efforts in nearby springs did not record the species. The only and last collection is the one in March 17, 1984.
result.geographicrange: This species is known from a single specimen, from a single location, Ojo la Trinidad, inland northern Mexico (Nearctic Realm) (Miller et al. 2005).
result.population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. It is presumed extinct. Surveys in nearby springs did not record this species.
result.habitat: The spring was devoid of vegetation, with a temperature of 19 °C (Miller et al. 2005). The spring where this species was collected was dried up by pumping the water for irrigation.
result.threats: Its spring habitat dried out because of excessive water extraction in the region (Miller et al. 2005).
result.conservationmeasures: There are no conservation measures for this species. It was kept in captivity, but since it was only a male specimen, reproduction was not possible (A. Valdes pers. comm. 2018). It is now considered extinct.
result.usetrade: It is unknown if this species was used or traded.
